content: I've just renumbered the validators - previously there were no validators numbered 2 and 3.

Hey Niako,
Following the discussion about tags in the forum, it seems this puzzle is the only one with the "shortest path" tag. Do you think we can replace it with the more classic "pathfinding" or did you make a difference between the two tags for a specific reason?
Thanks

https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/learning-tags-cleanup-normalization/186567/4

Great problem!
My only issue is that I don't think your last constraint is true: "There always exists a shortest path *within* the smallest rectangle containing all the given positions and clouds (hence, what is outside does not matter, you can arbitrarily consider it sunny or cloudy)."
In some cases, you need to walk just above/below/left/right of the clouds on the edges (e.g. in validator 2, but there may be others as well).
Therefore, I think that you should simply say that you can assume that it is sunny, unless specified otherwise or not say anything at all. It is clear that you do not need to walk further than the edges of the clouds.
Sorry for being so picky... This was a really fun problem to solve, and I'm ready to approve it as soon as I have your opinion on the above.

This is a challenging puzzle. My first trial was to "compress" the empty space, but failed at the bigger data sets because it is too complicated. Will try again later by "compressing" the clouds only. Do you think it is worthwhile to "compress" the empty space?
Moving this back to drafts for a while...

Here we go!

Complaint 1: clouds are given from "top-left", but axes aren't directed. I could disambiguate from the example, but that's distasteful. (and as far as I'm concerned, using (X,Y) coordinates instead of (i,j) defaults to a right-handed system; probably that's just cultural).
Suggestion: BOTH specify directions and match {(X,Y) <-> right-handed} ; {(i,j) <> left-handed}

Minor complaint 2: could we have S/D for ASCII-art path endpoints instead of @/X? (especially 'X'). (was a problem for me before the coordinate thing sorted out because too big a part of example 1 is top/down symmetrical)

Request 3: I don't think it actually happens in the cases, but my code kind of depends on clouds' W/H not being zero. Could the constraints please reflect that?

Food for thought 4: would "worst case"-like cases be in order? (I'm thinking whirlpool and nethack-style actual maze)

Food for thought 5: I'd love to see bigger scale variants of that. Possibly going beyond the horizontal/vertical boundaries limitation. Not sure how to properly go around the input size limitation there :/ A solo game maybe?

Praise 6: great puzzle!

For information (not necessarily action, I'm not too sure in a way or the other), my overcompressed version fails validator 4 but not the matching test (also tests Small Map 3 and Large Map 1 (but not validators), but those are later).

Great puzzle!

I won't approve until I solved it with my own code (I know how to, honest! I'm just lazy because there *is* a certain amount of tedium to it), I'm just commenting to try and get you to talk about how the test cases prevent obvious cheats.

You know it's good when you get:

Process has timed out. This may mean that your solution is not optimized enough to handle some cases.
It's not what one might think at first glance...
ah ok no ASCII art ;-)

I don't really know any obvious approach to cheat here. Approaches based on rescaling the map will approximate the result but it seems harder to refine them (locally or something) to get the exact result than to properly solve the problem in the first place. All other approaches I can think of are in the end more complicated than the expected solution. Maybe I'm missing something obvious, if you have any idea...

BTW here are the "compressed" maps of the last four tests https://framapic.org/gallery#36MLiwqn5yJ9/GuDatyt7RR6U.png,JZwJQjj9nBQT/6xlvonhp5v0t.png,pkpVS9ipIks3/h9oHPtOoBZ2i.png,gH0yisYluWRg/AjpdeJxcUXJB.png

Thanks a lot for your comment!

For some reason, when reading it, I realized I had written a different puzzle than the one I solved (mainly because I changed my mind so many times on how to write this to preserve the techniques while reducing the tediousness of the implementation, and wrote the statement several weeks after the solution, but without the correct representation in mind).
As an example, when writing the statement, I was considering the robot as a point and was thinking the answer to that input:
0 0
0 2
1
0 1 1 1
should be 2.

Obviously you managed to solve the problem despite that, probably assuming naturally that the space was discrete. Anyway I think I clarified the statement and addressed your complaints.

Because the actual puzzle does not resides in the pathfinding part, I would not consider mazes or such as worst case scenarios (that's actually why I did not create such case). Technically the complexity only depends on the number of clouds.

I don't think I understand your last paragraph.
~> Ready again (after a few fixes)

As you have guessed, the challenge does not resides in the pathfinding part (I could have asked almost anything else related to the map) but in the way to actually deal with the map. As both the clouds and empty spaces can be huge, my best hint would probably be to compress both (at the same time, in a common representation). Take time to think about it in order to find some convenient representation (there are some not too tedious ways to do it, my solution gives such an example).

Thanks for your comment!
You're absolutely right about V2 (I wrote the smallest cases last and I must have missed that) and, I've double-checked, it's actually the only occurrence of such issue (provided that you take into account the start/destination in the rectangle).
I've corrected it (because I simply don't want that to be possibly annoying) AND at the same time modified the constraints accordingly to what you've suggested (it's simpler that way, and anyway it's possible to solve the problem without strictly conforming to that).
Done!
thanks!

Point 1: thanks for fixing. I disagree with the choice, but at least it works :)

2/3: thanks for fixing, no disagreement.

4: Mmmmk. Not sure how you count/solve it; my code is something like O(D^2*lg D) with D=number of distinct coordinates in input; parsing O(sum of {compressed cloud} area). So [on reasonable maps] number of clouds not too relevant, as it's going to be bounded by input max size faster than it's going to be an issue.

Point-robot: now I'm the one not understanding. Why 2 and not, like, 1+sqrt 2? I don't see an "interesting" taxicab path of length 2 there. Maybe a picture?

My last paragraph: my N-1th iteration of the code solved everything except V4, SM1 and LM3. This is notable because traditionally the failures are all on the same side of the test/validator barrier. Preferably on the test side, but most commonly on the validator side. Here it's mostly on test (good), but one exception, all the more weird that it's on one of the earlier pairs that I'd assume to be "easier".
I neither investigated my code about it nor how it interacted with the cases, so I'm not drawing any conclusions here in a way or another. I just mentioned in case it could ring a more accurate bell to you who actually designed the cases.

4: Ok but your D = O(N). If you consider that the input size, or even the coordinates, are bounded by a constant, then the complexity falls down to O(1) ;-) (that's why I count like that, but other than that you're right "on reasonable maps").

For the small example: Simply the straight line from (0,0) to (0,2), considering (wrongfully with the current statement/solution) the robot as a point and assuming it is allowed to move along the cloud (as long as it's not inside).

Ok now I understand the last paragraph and, no, I don't know what could be the specific problem here. Anyway I might consider adding a few additional pathological maps to wash away even more close solution codes.

4: Yeah I wasn't playing complexity semantics, just pointing out that in the current state of CG, N is necessarily low.

Point-robot: got it now. (what I was missing from my discrete anchor: the point is top-left of the squares, not in the middle). IMHO think it's better as squares, if only to keep the mathematical cleanliness that a cloud is the sum of its parts, which you wouldn't necessarily get if you were allowed to cut along the sides.

Last paragraph: that was random information, not a problem!
